chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A durable compromise would keep states administering elections but make the outcome track the national will more reliably, so fewer voters feel their ballot is “wasted” because of winner-take-all rules. One approach is to pair a national popular-vote trigger (such as an interstate compact that activates only with strong participation and a clear margin) with proportional elector allocation in each state and a modernized House to reduce small-state distortion. Alongside any structural change, baseline national rules for ballot access, counting timelines, audits, and automatic recounts would help both sides trust close results while preserving the federal character of the system.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: A practical reform should keep states’ administrative role and the federal balance, while making outcomes track the national popular will more closely and reducing winner-take-all distortions. A strong middle path is to require proportional allocation of electors in every state (ideally with an expanded House to lessen small-state overweights), alongside clear nationwide standards for ballot access, auditing, and automatic recount thresholds. States that prefer a faster transition could also support the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, provided the rules are transparent, legally durable, and easy for voters to understand.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: A durable middle-ground reform should keep states administering elections while ensuring the presidency reflects the choice of voters nationwide and that no community feels written off. A practical path is either the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or a rule requiring proportional allocation of electors in every state, paired with expanding the House to reduce small-state distortion and lessen “winner-take-all” incentives. Whatever model is chosen, it should include clear national baselines for ballot access, chain-of-custody, audits, and automatic recount thresholds so close elections are transparent, secure, and trusted.
